questions.text: 30-year young female is diagnosed as having IBS. Which of the following is not a feature of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Nocturnal diarrhoea

  • Nocturnal diarrhoea does not occur in IBS. Night time sleep in not interrupted in IBS. Altered bowel habits and altered GI motility are features of IBS and leads to recurrent abdominal pain.

Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Irritable Bowel Syndrome

  • Recurrent abdominal pain, on average, at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months, associated with $\geq 2$ of the following criteria:
    • Related to defection
    • Associated with a change in frequency of stool
    • Associated with a change in form (appearance) of stool
  • Criteria fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months prior to diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about mechanism of action of Lubiprostone used in IBS-C?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Increase intestinal chloride secretion

  • Lubiprostone is a secretagogue that acts on intestinal enterocytes by activating chloride channels on the apical membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells.
  • To maintain electroneutrality, sodium ions follow the chloride ions into the intestinal lumen. This ionic movement creates an osmotic gradient that draws water into the lumen. The influx of water softens the stool and increases intestinal fluid content, which helps relieve constipation by promoting easier bowel movements.
  • This mechanism makes lubiprostone an effective treatment for constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS-C) and chronic idiopathic constipation, as it improves stool consistency and bowel movement frequency by enhancing intestinal fluid secretion and motility.

questions.text: 28-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and diarrhea lasting several months. Over the time, the patient developed periods of constipation in between diarrheal episodes. There is also unintended weight loss and occasional low-grade fever. Blood tests reveal normocytic normochromic anemia and elevated inflammatory markers. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: IBD

  • The alternating diarrhea and constipation could initially suggest a functional disorder like IBS; however, systemic signs such as unintended weight loss, low-grade fever, and anemia point to an inflammatory or organic cause.
  • The presence of normocytic normochromic anemia and raised inflammatory markers indicates ongoing inflammation and chronic disease ie IBD.
  • Crohn disease involves the ileum causing bile acid malabsorption and leads to diarrhea. Same patient can later develop strictures in gut and develops constipation.

questions.text: Which of the following diet is best suited for patients with IBS?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Low FODMAP diet

  • IBS patients have bloating and distention. They get benefit from Low FODMAP diet that involves restricting certain fermentable carbohydrates known as FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) that are poorly absorbed in the small intestine.
  • These FODMAPs can cause symptoms of IBS such as bloating, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and gas due to their fermentation by gut bacteria and osmotic effects in the intestine.
  • Option A is for celiac sprue. Option B and C is for weight loss

questions.text: 30-year-old lady with GERD symptoms underwent a UGI endoscopy that shows loss of vascular pattern, multiple rings and trachealization appearance of oesophagus. Which of the following is correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Eosinophilic esophagitis

  • Key words are “trachealization” or ringed appearance of oesophagus which is seen in eosinophilic esophagitis. It is associated with GERD.

Incorret Options:

Option A - IBS-D (Irritable bowel syndrome -Diarrhea predominant): This is a functional bowel disorder and unrelated to oesophageal endoscopic findings.

Option B - Barrett's oesophagus: Characterized by a salmon-pink, velvety mucosa replacing normal pale squamous mucosa, usually involves mucosal metaplasia at the distal esophagus, not multiple rings or corrugation.

Option D - Achalasia cardia: Endoscopy often shows a dilated esophagus with retained food and smooth oesophageal mucosa

questions.text: 65-year-old man with obesity and hypertension develops haematochezia needing hospitalization. Which of the following is probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Diverticulitis

  • Leading cause of haematochezia in geriatric age group and needing immediate hospitalization is diverticulitis. Option B will cause symptoms like constipation, weight loss over a period of time. Option C will present with recurrent abdominal pain with diarrhea alternating with constipation. Option D will not require hospitalization in most cases.
